Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Digital Forensics and Image Recognition Software

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a study of algorithmic systems used to automatically identify suspected victims and exploiters, which become part of the arsenal of tools deployed by anti-trafficking networks, which include law enforcement.

The research will result in a dissertation and trained professional. Results will be disseminated to a wide range of stake-holders.

ProgramReference.Text: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH

POR.DRECONTENT:
The trafficking and exploitation of young people has received heightened global attention since the passage of the UN Protocol on Human Trafficking in 2000, which set international standards criminalizing human trafficking for the purposes of labor or sexual exploitation. In the two decades since, publicity campaigns by anti-trafficking activist organizations have taken increasingly innovative and high-tech approaches to garner public support for their policy and program agendas. My dissertation explores how such campaigns work in tandem with the new digital techniques employed by police and activists to investigate child abuse, exploitation, and trafficking cases. My findings are based on three years of ethnographic fieldwork in Thailand, the Netherlands, and throughout the United States. At each of these sites, I interviewed technology specialists, activists, and law enforcement personnel working on image detection software, avatar design, and data collection to address the online sexual exploitation of children. In my dissertation I describe how new technologies are designed and implemented through various collaborations between local and international organizations, from policing bodies to software companies and non-governmental organizations. Through this research I make policy and practical recommendations regarding the extent to which such technology must be paired with human experiential knowledge and youth survivor input.


Last Modified: 01/13/2016
Modified by: Mitali Thakor
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The trafficking and exploitation of young people has received heightened global attention since the passage of the UN Protocol on Human Trafficking in 2000, which set international standards criminalizing human trafficking for the purposes of labor or sexual exploitation. In the two decades since, publicity campaigns by anti-trafficking activist organizations have taken increasingly innovative and high-tech approaches to garner public support for their policy and program agendas. My dissertation explores how such campaigns work in tandem with the new digital techniques employed by police and activists to investigate child abuse, exploitation, and trafficking cases. My findings are based on three years of ethnographic fieldwork in Thailand, the Netherlands, and throughout the United States. At each of these sites, I interviewed technology specialists, activists, and law enforcement personnel working on image detection software, avatar design, and data collection to address the online sexual exploitation of children. In my dissertation I describe how new technologies are designed and implemented through various collaborations between local and international organizations, from policing bodies to software companies and non-governmental organizations. Through this research I make policy and practical recommendations regarding the extent to which such technology must be paired with human experiential knowledge and youth survivor input.
